title: Angle Relationships
description: Explore complementary, supplementary, and vertically opposite angles, and angles formed by parallel lines and transversals.
objectives: Identify and use complementary, supplementary, and vertically opposite angles
Understand angle relationships when parallel lines are cut by a transversal
Calculate unknown angles using these relationships

sections.title: Angles Have Relationships Too!
sections.content:
When two lines cross, or when a line cuts through parallel lines, the angles formed have special relationships. Knowing these relationships lets you find missing angles without measuring — just by using logic and a bit of calculation.

These angle rules are the foundation of geometry and are used everywhere from engineering to art.

sections.title: Complementary and Supplementary Angles
sections.content:
**Complementary angles** add up to $90°$:
$$\alpha + \beta = 90°$$
If one angle is $35°$, its complement is $90° - 35° = 55°$.

**Supplementary angles** add up to $180°$ (they form a straight line):
$$\alpha + \beta = 180°$$
If one angle is $110°$, its supplement is $180° - 110° = 70°$.

Memory trick: **C** comes before **S** in the alphabet, and **90** comes before **180**.
- **C**omplementary = **90°**
- **S**upplementary = **180°**

sections.title: Vertically Opposite Angles
sections.content:
When two straight lines cross, they form two pairs of **vertically opposite angles**.

Vertically opposite angles are **always equal**.

If two lines cross and one angle is $130°$, then:
- The angle opposite it is also $130°$
- The two adjacent angles are each $180° - 130° = 50°$

All four angles always add up to $360°$ ($130 + 50 + 130 + 50 = 360$).

sections.title: Parallel Lines and Transversals
sections.content:
When a line (called a **transversal**) crosses two **parallel lines**, it creates $8$ angles with special relationships:

**Corresponding angles** are in the same position at each intersection — they are **equal**.

**Alternate angles** are on opposite sides of the transversal, between the parallel lines — they are **equal**.

**Co-interior (same-side interior) angles** are on the same side of the transversal, between the parallel lines — they are **supplementary** (add up to $180°$).

If you know just **one** of the eight angles, you can find all the others!

sections.title: Finding Angles with Parallel Lines
sections.content: Two parallel lines are cut by a transversal. One angle is $65°$. Find all other angles.
steps: Vertically opposite: $65°$ (opposite angle at the same intersection)
Supplementary angles at the same intersection: $180° - 65° = 115°$
The vertically opposite of $115°$ is also $115°$
At the other intersection, corresponding angles are equal: $65°$ and $115°$
And their vertically opposite angles: $65°$ and $115°$
All eight angles: four are $65°$ and four are $115°$

sections.title: Angle Summary Table
sections.content:
| Angle Relationship | Rule |
|---|---|
| Complementary | Sum $= 90°$ |
| Supplementary | Sum $= 180°$ |
| Vertically opposite | Equal |
| Corresponding (parallel lines) | Equal |
| Alternate (parallel lines) | Equal |
| Co-interior (parallel lines) | Sum $= 180°$ |

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
- Complementary angles sum to $90°$; supplementary angles sum to $180°$
- Vertically opposite angles are equal
- When a transversal crosses parallel lines: corresponding and alternate angles are equal, co-interior angles sum to $180°$
- Knowing one angle can help you find all others

workedExamples.title: Using Multiple Angle Rules
workedExamples.problem: Two parallel lines are cut by a transversal. An angle of $72°$ is marked. Find the co-interior angle.
workedExamples.explanation: Co-interior angles (also called same-side interior or allied angles) always add up to $180°$ when the lines are parallel.

workedExamples.title: Finding Multiple Unknown Angles
workedExamples.problem: Two straight lines cross. One angle is $x°$ and the adjacent angle is $(3x + 20)°$. Find $x$.
steps: Adjacent angles on a straight line are supplementary
workedExamples.explanation: We used the fact that adjacent angles on a straight line sum to $180°$ to set up an equation and solve for $x$.

title: Transformations on the Cartesian Plane and Properties of Quadrilaterals
description: Perform transformations using coordinates and explore the properties of different quadrilaterals.
objectives: Perform translations, reflections, and rotations using coordinate rules
Identify and describe properties of different quadrilaterals
Classify quadrilaterals based on their properties

sections.title: Coordinates and Quadrilaterals
sections.content: In Level 6, you learned about transformations and the Cartesian plane. Now we'll combine these — performing precise transformations using coordinate rules. We'll also take a deep dive into **quadrilaterals** (four-sided shapes) and their special properties.

sections.title: Transformations Using Coordinates
sections.content:
**Translation:** Add the same values to every point.
- Translate $(x, y)$ by $3$ right and $2$ down: $(x + 3, y - 2)$

**Reflection in the $y$-axis:** Change the sign of $x$.
- $(x, y) \to (-x, y)$
- Example: $(3, 5) \to (-3, 5)$

**Reflection in the $x$-axis:** Change the sign of $y$.
- $(x, y) \to (x, -y)$
- Example: $(3, 5) \to (3, -5)$

**Rotation $180°$ about the origin:** Change both signs.
- $(x, y) \to (-x, -y)$
- Example: $(3, 5) \to (-3, -5)$

**Rotation $90°$ clockwise about the origin:**
- $(x, y) \to (y, -x)$

sections.title: Properties of Quadrilaterals
sections.content:
All quadrilaterals have $4$ sides and interior angles summing to $360°$. Here are the special types:

**Square**: All sides equal, all angles $90°$, diagonals equal and bisect at $90°$

**Rectangle**: Opposite sides equal, all angles $90°$, diagonals equal and bisect each other

**Rhombus**: All sides equal, opposite angles equal, diagonals bisect at $90°$

**Parallelogram**: Opposite sides parallel and equal, opposite angles equal, diagonals bisect each other

**Trapezium**: Exactly one pair of parallel sides

**Kite**: Two pairs of adjacent sides equal, one pair of opposite angles equal, diagonals cross at $90°$

sections.title: The Quadrilateral Family Tree
sections.content:
Quadrilaterals are related:

- A **square** is a special rectangle (with all sides equal)
- A **square** is also a special rhombus (with right angles)
- Both rectangles and rhombuses are special **parallelograms**
- A parallelogram is a special **trapezium** (with both pairs of sides parallel)

So every square is a rectangle, but not every rectangle is a square!

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
- Transformations can be described precisely using coordinate rules
- Reflection in the $y$-axis: $(x, y) \to (-x, y)$; in the $x$-axis: $(x, y) \to (x, -y)$
- $180°$ rotation: $(x, y) \to (-x, -y)$
- Quadrilaterals have angle sum $360°$ and are classified by their sides, angles, and diagonal properties
- Squares, rectangles, rhombuses, and parallelograms form a hierarchy

workedExamples.title: Combined Transformation
workedExamples.problem: Point $A(2, -3)$ is reflected in the $x$-axis and then translated $4$ units left. What are the final coordinates?
workedExamples.explanation: We applied each transformation in order: first the reflection, then the translation. The order matters!

workedExamples.title: Identifying a Quadrilateral
workedExamples.problem: A quadrilateral has vertices at $A(0, 0)$, $B(4, 0)$, $C(4, 3)$, and $D(0, 3)$. Identify the type of quadrilateral.
steps: Opposite sides are equal and parallel. All angles are $90°$
But adjacent sides are NOT equal ($4 \neq 3$)
workedExamples.explanation: Opposite sides are equal and all angles are right angles, but the sides are not all the same length, so it's a rectangle (not a square).
